elements.title: Axel Downard-Wilke (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Axel Downard-Wilke (pictured) led a campaign in 2020 to have macrons used in Māori place names in Wikipedia articles?

elements.title: icosian game (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that although the icosian game was advertised as a "highly amusing game for the drawing room", it was too easy to play and not a commercial success?

elements.title: Sim0ne (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that prior to embarking on a music career during the COVID-19 pandemic, the DJ Sim0ne placed fifth on the eleventh series of Britain's Next Top Model in 2017?

elements.title: Eldridge Street Synagogue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the architects of the Eldridge Street Synagogue were Catholics who had never designed a synagogue before?

elements.title: Theo Benedet (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Theo Benedet is the first offensive lineman to be named the best Canadian university football lineman two years in a row?

elements.title: Bulgur Palas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the historic mansion Bulgur Palas in Istanbul hosted a birdhouse for hundreds of domestic canaries in one room during its ownership by the Ottoman Bank?

elements.title: Nellie McCoy (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that actress Nellie McCoy suffered a mental breakdown after her theatre performance was criticized, leading to her being committed to a sanatorium?

elements.title: search for clown pornography (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that women were 33 percent more likely than men to search for clown pornography in 2016?

elements.title: United States' Telegraph (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the chief editor of the United States' Telegraph allegedly gouged a rival reporter's eyes inside a Senate office?
